Let M be the mass of the ice+diamond and let D be the mass of just the diamond. Temporarily change the diamond into ice of the same mass D, leaving the total mass M unchanged. Then the volume V of water displaced will also be unchanged because the weight of the water displaced (which equals the buoyant force) must still balance the same Mg. Thus far the water level has remained unchanged. Next, let all (including the extra bit) of the ice melt. As is well known, this also won't change the water level, because ice of mass M has been turned into water of the same mass whose volume V equals the displacement. Finally turn water of mass D back into diamond. Since the diamond sunk to the bottom, we know it's denser than the water. Therefore the diamond of mass D will take up less volume then the water it replaced, so the total volume — and hence the water level — will go down in the end.

So the water level will go down for denser-than-water inclusions (like diamonds) and go up for less-dense-than-water inclusions (like air bubbles).

The water level in the glass is a proxy for volume. Call the initial volume of water before adding the ice cube V0. When you add the ice cube and diamond, the volume as indicated by the water level increases by the water displaced. Call this new volume V1.

Since the ice cube and diamond float, the water displaced is equivalent in mass to the ice cube and diamond.

Now the ice cube melts. But the diamond doesn't. Unless the water is really hot. But then it would be vapor anyway, so no, the diamond doesn't melt.

The new volume as indicated by the water level is equivalent to the original volume V0 plus the water displaced by the melted ice cube (a.k.a. water) and the diamond. Call this V2. Since the diamond sinks, this displaced water is equal in volume. So V2 = V0 + the volume of the melted ice cube + the volume of the diamond.

Clearly V2 is higher than V0, but I don't think that's what you are asking. Is V2 higher than V1?

V1-V0 is the volume of water which would have the same mass as the ice cube (Mi) and the diamond (Md). Density is mass/volume, so if the density of water is Dw, then V1-V0 = (Mi+Md)/Dw

V2-V0 is the volume of the melted ice cube (Mi/Dw) and the diamond (Md/Dd). So V2-V0 = Mi/Dw + Md/Dd

Since V0 and Mi/D2 cancel out, the difference between V2 and V1 is simply due to the mass of the diamond, either at the density of water, or at the density of diamond. V2-V1 = Md/Dd - Md/Dw

Since the density of diamond is greater than the density of water, Md/Dd < Md/Dw (greater denominator and all). So V2-V1 is negative. In other words:

V2 < V1

-> If it would be only the ice cube, the level of water wouldn't move since the law of archimedes states that the upwards force is equal to the volume of displaced water. Because of the conservation of mass, if the cube melts, it would still weigh 917kg of liquid water (same amount of atoms than before), now taking up 0.917m3 of volume since the density of water is 1000kg/m3. Now when it melts, the diamond will be submerged and displace a volume of 1L (since its density equals 3.5kg/L). Less water is displaced, thus the level of water will go down.

Now that the ice has melted, the melted ice the exact same density as the water (being water itself), so it is still 'supporting' the ice, so to speak. You can also look at it in terms of the pressure on the glass bottom. In both cases, the bottom of the glass must support the weight of everything (water, ice and diamond), but the only thing acting on it is the water pressure, equal to m*g*h (h being the depth of the water). When the diamond falls to the floor of the glass, the glass is supporting some of the diamond's weight directly. So the water pressure is necessarily less if the glass is supporting the same weight. TL;DR: The water level will go down. The diamond displaces its weight in water when it floats in its ice cube, but its volume in water when it sinks. Its volume in water is less than the volume of its weight in water, so it displaces less.

Let's consider an extreme case: an ice cube with a tiny but mega-dense gold pellet inside it. Assuming it's floating, it will displace water equal to its weight. Part of that displacement is due to the weight of the ice and part is due to the weight of the gold pellet, and since the pellet is so dense, it accounts for a large fraction of that weight. The ice becomes water as it melts, so its volume becomes the same as the volume of the water it displaced. In other words, the melting ice does not affect the water level. But the gold pellet, once it is free of the ice, does not have enough volume to displace its weight in water--that's why it sinks. The large portion of the displacement that used to be due to the weight of the gold, when it floated in the ice cube, is now due to the volume of the gold pellet. Since the density of gold is so much higher than that of water, its volume in water is a lot less than its weight in water. Thus, the water level will go down, since the displacement of the gold pellet has shifted from its massive weight to its small volume. The same logic applies to the diamond, since it is denser than water.

This entire explanation is based on the assumption that the ice cube with the diamond in it floats in water, and the key fact that a floating object displaces its weight in water while a sinking object displaces its volume.
